message_content:
Over the past two years, the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) has been using data from the MSNAs to conduct research on the severity of internal displacement. Our research complements the figures in the Global Report on Internal Displacement, offering additional insights that help governments, humanitarian organisations, donors, and other key actors in prioritising their responses to displacement situations. This work aligns with OCHA's durable solutions framework, measuring progress in addressing specific displacement-related vulnerabilities that can prevent displaced people from accessing durable solutions. You can find the findings from our previous analyses on the IDMC Severity Assessments page.

Accessing the full MSNA data from Mozambique would allow us to fill in an important data gap and provide a more comprehensive overview of internal displacement dynamics in the country.

These two notes describe the input data, estimation and projection methods, and strengths and limitations of the resulting COD-PS update. These notes are made available to end-users of the 2024 COD-PS update.", "name": "cod-ps-ukr", "notes": "![UNFPA Logo](https://data.humdata.org/image/2021-08-05-143409.352392UNFPA-logo.jpg)

Subnational Population Statistics are produced by and contributed to HDX by [UNFPA](https://data.humdata.org/organization/unfpa) and, in the case of Ukraine, are exceptionally shared by OCHA Ukraine with the approval of UNFPA.

The 2024 Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) update for Ukraine presents raion-level (ADM-2), oblast-level (ADM-1) and national-level (ADM-0) estimates of population size by sex and standard 5-year demographic age groups. The 2024 COD-PS update revises the 2023 COD-PS update and 2022 COD-PS update produced by UNFPA, by accounting for recent population change due to mobility, mortality and fertility dynamics.

This COD-PS update was prepared by the United Nations Population Fund, UNFPA. This update was prepared in consultation with the Humanitarian Country Team and UN Country Team in Ukraine, as well as national partners including the Institute for Demography and Quality of Life Problems, Ukraine and the State Statistics Service of Ukraine.

The 2024 COD-PS update, like all COD-PS updates, is strictly a humanitarian data product of the United Nations aligned to the "best available humanitarian data standard". It does not represent or, in any way, replace official statistics or official population projections of the Government of Ukraine and it is not intended to meet the international standards of official statistics.

The Ukraine Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) 2024 is a restricted dataset, in line with applicable national laws and the host country agreement with the United Nations. It is shared only with the Ukraine Humanitarian Country Team, UN Country Team in Ukraine, and the Government of Ukraine.", "num_resources": 0, "num_tags": 1, "organization": {"id": "40cfa9c2-59b6-44c2-bd34-cf99ce438067", "name": "ocha-ukraine", "title": "OCHA Ukraine", "type": "organization", "description": "United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in Ukraine.", "image_url": "", "created": "2015-06-11T18:38:28.045449", "is_organization": true, "approval_status": "approved", "state": "active"}, "overdue_date": "2025-12-09T08:55:22", "owner_org": "40cfa9c2-59b6-44c2-bd34-cf99ce438067", "package_creator": "shcheglov", "pageviews_last_14_days": 71, "private": false, "qa_completed": false, "review_date": "2024-09-25T19:23:00.253351", "solr_additions": "{"countries": ["Ukraine"]}", "state": "active", "subnational": "1", "title": "Ukraine: Subnational Population Statistics", "total_res_downloads": 8, "type": "dataset", "updated_by_script": "HDXINTERNAL:HDXPythonLibrary/6.2.0-CODs (2024-10-09T21:51:01.022328)", "url": null, "version": null, "groups": [{"description": "", "display_name": "Ukraine", "id": "ukr", "image_display_url": "", "name": "ukr", "title": "Ukraine"}], "tags": [{"display_name": "baseline population", "id": "db8205e9-b61c-4df7-a987-1a2658ed8666", "name": "baseline population", "state": "active", "vocabulary_id": "b891512e-9516-4bf5-962a-7a289772a2a1"}], "resources": [], "relationships_as_subject": [], "relationships_as_object": [], "is_fresh": true, "update_status": "fresh", "x_resource_grouping": []}}

Overall, 3.4 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance and protection .

It is therefore necessary to update the previous multi-sector needs assessment reports (IAVA, Trend Analysis, Winter Assessment) with a new and relevant data, and further investigate the trends of the changing humanitarian situation on the ground through both secondary data review from other humanitarian actors, as well as primary field collection of data to fill the gaps identified in the humanitarian data available.

General Objective To understand and track changes in humanitarian needs of populations living in conflict affected areas in government controlled areas of Ukraine.

message_content:
Syrian Forum is dedicated to empowering Syrians to rebuild their lives and their communities through sustainable life-changing programs and services. 

Our comprehensive strategy includes education, training, job placement, economic empowerment, and research studies. We also prioritize women empowerment and child protection, working to ensure that all Syrians have the support and resources they need to thrive and succeed.

How we can do it? Depends on a real, updated data that reflect the current situation.

Data plays a crucial role in advocacy and securing donations by establishing credibility, showcasing impact, and building trust.

message_content:
My name is Jéssica Pereira, and I’m a Political Science and International Relations Master’s student at NOVA University of Lisbon – School of Social Sciences and Humanities. I’m currently in my second year and working on my dissertation. The central research question guiding my work is: “How can the inclusion of gender in the definitions of forced migrant have an impact on women's security, taking Afghanistan as a case study from 2016 to 2021?”.

Given the centrality of women's database in my analysis, I'm keenly searching for quantitative data of Afghan forced migrant women.
extras: {"country": "Portugal", "organization_id": "NOVA University of Lisbon \u2013 School of Social Sciences and Humanities (NOVA FCSH) ", "organization_name": "NOVA University of Lisbon \u2013 School of Social Sciences and Humanities (NOVA FCSH) ", "organization_member": false, "organization_type": "academic_research", "intend": "Academic", "dataset_dict": {"archived": false, "author": null, "author_email": null, "batch": "93c52ec2-af4f-4c42-b289-47be54a087d7", "caveats": "The Whole of Afghanistan Assessment (WoAA 2020) implemented a quantitative methodology reliant upon approximately 12,592 household level surveys in accessible parts of Afghanistan from 04 August 2020 to 05 September 2020. The Covid-19 pandemic increased commodity prices, decreased livelihood opportunities, and strained Afghanistan\u2019s weak health and social service infrastructures. Given the generally poor mobile and WiFi services across Afghanistan and the particularly poor access that vulnerable and displaced populations have to mobile phones and computers, face to face interviews were conducted. However, in recognition of the \u201cDue No Harm\u201d and \u201cDuty of Care\u201d principles, new procedures and trainings were established to limit both field staff and respondent exposure to Covid-19, survey questions were limited to only those crucial to cluster planning, the confidence rate for the sampling was increased, and focus group discussions (FGDs) were eliminated. \r\nData collection was conducted using stratified cluster sampling with a 95/5 at national level for all population groups. To reduce gender bias, male-female enumerator pairs conducted assessments in provinces where it was feasible to do so. Male-female enumerator pairs interviewed one male member and one female member of each household, when possible, using the same questionnaire. message_content:
I hope this message finds you well. My name is Jingru Ni, an undergraduate student at Tsinghua University in China. I am currently working on a non-profit research project focusing on internal displacement in Somalia. My research aims to provide valuable insights and recommendations that can contribute to improving the lives of internally displaced persons in the country.
In the course of my research, I have realized the critical role this dataset could play in my research. Therefore, I am writing to formally request access to it. I assure you that my use of the data will be solely for non-profit research purposes, adhering strictly to any terms of use or data protection guidelines that your organization may have in place.

message_content: We would like to study the accessibility of medical resources for residents under different external influences (such as disasters and wars) on medical facilities, hoping to apply the research findings to serve humanitarian relief.

These notes are made available to end-users of the 2024 COD-PS update.", "name": "cod-ps-ukr", "notes": "![UNFPA Logo](https://data.humdata.org/image/2021-08-05-143409.352392UNFPA-logo.jpg)

Subnational Population Statistics are produced by and contributed to HDX by [UNFPA](https://data.humdata.org/organization/unfpa) and, in the case of Ukraine, are exceptionally shared by OCHA Ukraine with the approval of UNFPA.

The 2024 Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) update for Ukraine presents raion-level (ADM-2), oblast-level (ADM-1) and national-level (ADM-0) estimates of population size by sex and standard 5-year demographic age groups. The 2024 COD-PS update revises the 2023 COD-PS update and 2022 COD-PS update produced by UNFPA, by accounting for recent population change due to mobility, mortality and fertility dynamics.

This COD-PS update was prepared by the United Nations Population Fund, UNFPA. This update was prepared in consultation with the Humanitarian Country Team and UN Country Team in Ukraine, as well as national partners including the Institute for Demography and Quality of Life Problems, Ukraine and the State Statistics Service of Ukraine.

The 2024 COD-PS update, like all COD-PS updates, is strictly a humanitarian data product of the United Nations aligned to the "best available humanitarian data standard". It does not represent or, in any way, replace official statistics or official population projections of the Government of Ukraine and it is not intended to meet the international standards of official statistics.

The Ukraine Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) 2024 is a restricted dataset, in line with applicable national laws and the host country agreement with the United Nations. message_content:
In northwest Syria, the White Helmets, a dedicated humanitarian organization, are seeking accurate and updated population data. We need information disaggregated by sex and age, as well as by administrative areas. This data is crucial for us to understand the specific needs of groups like children and the elderly.

With this information, we can tailor our aid efforts more effectively, allocate resources to areas with the greatest needs, and prepare for potential emergencies, such as natural disasters or disease outbreaks. We kindly request your assistance in providing this detailed population data, which will help us enhance our humanitarian operations and ultimately improve the well-being of the Syrian people. Thank you for your support.

message_content: GIS Analyst supporting the Humanitarian response supporting Ukraine.
extras:
{"country": "United States", "organization_id": "USAID", "organization_name": "USAID", "organization_member": false, "organization_type": "government", "intend": "Advocacy", "dataset_dict": {"archived": false, "author": null, "author_email": null, "cod_level": "cod-standard", "creator_user_id": "ee6e4f19-837f-4849-b164-80deab359fd8", "data_update_frequency": "365", "dataset_date": "[2024-07-15T00:00:00 TO 2024-07-15T23:59:59]", "dataset_preview": "first_resource", "dataset_source": "United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA)", "due_date": "2025-10-10T08:55:22", "field_names": "SADD,Total Population,COD-AB reference data", "file_types": "Excel,PDF", "has_geodata": false, "has_quickcharts": false, "has_showcases": false, "id": "8a3549d1-ca04-4c12-833e-05ef521b594e", "is_requestdata_type": true, "isopen": false, "last_modified": "2024-10-10T08:55:22.905926", "license_title": null, "maintainer": "ee6e4f19-837f-4849-b164-80deab359fd8", "metadata_created": "2024-09-20T12:45:44.096037", "metadata_modified": "2024-10-10T08:55:22.905926", "methodology": "Other", "methodology_other": "A technical accompanying note and an end-user release note (.pdf) have been prepared by UNFPA and will be provided with the data. These two notes describe the input data, estimation and projection methods, and strengths and limitations of the resulting COD-PS update. These notes are made available to end-users of the 2024 COD-PS update.", "name": "cod-ps-ukr", "notes": "![UNFPA Logo](https://data.humdata.org/image/2021-08-05-143409.352392UNFPA-logo.jpg)

Subnational Population Statistics are produced by and contributed to HDX by [UNFPA](https://data.humdata.org/organization/unfpa) and, in the case of Ukraine, are exceptionally shared by OCHA Ukraine with the approval of UNFPA.

The 2024 Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) update for Ukraine presents raion-level (ADM-2), oblast-level (ADM-1) and national-level (ADM-0) estimates of population size by sex and standard 5-year demographic age groups. The 2024 COD-PS update revises the 2023 COD-PS update and 2022 COD-PS update produced by UNFPA, by accounting for recent population change due to mobility, mortality and fertility dynamics.

This COD-PS update was prepared by the United Nations Population Fund, UNFPA. This update was prepared in consultation with the Humanitarian Country Team and UN Country Team in Ukraine, as well as national partners including the Institute for Demography and Quality of Life Problems, Ukraine and the State Statistics Service of Ukraine.

The 2024 COD-PS update, like all COD-PS updates, is strictly a humanitarian data product of the United Nations aligned to the "best available humanitarian data standard". It does not represent or, in any way, replace official statistics or official population projections of the Government of Ukraine and it is not intended to meet the international standards of official statistics.

The Ukraine Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) 2024 is a restricted dataset, in line with applicable national laws and the host country agreement with the United Nations. It is shared only with the Ukraine Humanitarian Country Team, UN Country Team in Ukraine, and the Government of Ukraine.", "num_resources": 0, "num_tags": 1, "organization": {"id": "40cfa9c2-59b6-44c2-bd34-cf99ce438067", "name": "ocha-ukraine", "title": "OCHA Ukraine", "type": "organization", "description": "United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in Ukraine.", "image_url": "", "created": "2015-06-11T18:38:28.045449", "is_organization": true, "approval_status": "approved", "state": "active"}, "overdue_date": "2025-12-09T08:55:22", "owner_org": "40cfa9c2-59b6-44c2-bd34-cf99ce438067", "package_creator": "shcheglov", "pageviews_last_14_days": 79, "private": false, "qa_completed": false, "review_date": "2024-09-25T19:23:00.253351", "solr_additions": "{"countries": ["Ukraine"]}", "state": "active", "subnational": "1", "title": "Ukraine: Subnational Population Statistics", "total_res_downloads": 8, "type": "dataset", "updated_by_script": "HDXINTERNAL:HDXPythonLibrary/6.2.0-CODs (2024-10-09T21:51:01.022328)", "url": null, "version": null, "groups": [{"description": "", "display_name": "Ukraine", "id": "ukr", "image_display_url": "", "name": "ukr", "title": "Ukraine"}], "tags": [{"display_name": "baseline population", "id": "db8205e9-b61c-4df7-a987-1a2658ed8666", "name": "baseline population", "state": "active", "vocabulary_id": "b891512e-9516-4bf5-962a-7a289772a2a1"}], "resources": [], "relationships_as_subject": [], "relationships_as_object": [], "is_fresh": true, "update_status": "fresh", "x_resource_grouping": []}}

message_content: My team is working on a prospective analysis regarding the social tensions impact of displacement in Lebanon.
extras:

message_content:
To Whom It May Concern,

I am a German architecture student at the Technical University of Munich, currently working on my master's thesis. My research focuses on “Design with Water Challenges,” addressing the growing impact of extreme water-related conditions, such as droughts and flooding.

Given Timor-Leste’s particular vulnerability to these challenges, I am keenly interested in exploring and proposing architectural solutions suited to such conditions. My project involves in-depth research on a selected site and the development of a concept that translates water-related challenges into architectural responses.

For my research, I would greatly appreciate the opportunity to access further insights and resources available on your website.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Timor-Leste (CVTL), Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Open Mapping Hub Asia Pacific, Civil Protection Timor Leste, Contributors to the OpenStreetMap 2023, OSM Community Timor Leste", "creator_user_id": "6b9fbd55-6752-4fd3-a306-49a7f5c1bf48", "data_update_frequency": "-2", "dataset_date": "[2023-09-11T00:00:00 TO 2023-09-23T23:59:59]", "dataset_preview": "first_resource", "dataset_source": "Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre, Open Mapping Hub Asia Pacific, OpenStreetMap Contributors", "field_names": "OSM building footprint,critical infrastructures,floods,early warning,flood impacts,capacities", "file_types": "Excel Table,Shapefile,JSON", "has_geodata": false, "has_quickcharts": false, "has_showcases": true, "id": "d52028c5-3327-4cd4-8838-e445253b8f34", "is_requestdata_type": true, "isopen": false, "last_modified": "2024-01-03T13:45:22.938114", "license_title": null, "maintainer": "6b9fbd55-6752-4fd3-a306-49a7f5c1bf48", "metadata_created": "2023-12-16T19:14:35.666815", "metadata_modified": "2024-01-03T13:45:22.938114", "methodology": "Other", "methodology_other": "OpenStreetMap Field Data Collection using KoboCollect & OSM remote mapping through the HOTOSM Tasking Manager", "name": "anticipatory-mapping-timor-leste", "notes": "This data package contains field data collected during anticipatory mapping in Timor Leste. The data collection focused on completing critical infrastructure mapping in the focus areas, collecting information of historic flood events, flood impacts, and early warnings. 
This data package is available upon request only due to containing household-level information. However, all structural building data has been directly imported into OpenStreetMap and is openly accessible.

The project involved several key stages:

•	Initial updates and completion of building footprints in OpenStreetMap in focus areas via remote mapping using satellite imagery before commencing field mapping.

•	Comprehensive mapping of all critical infrastructure buildings in designated areas, gathering bbuilding attributes like building use, names, etc.

•	Collection of specific building features indicating susceptibility to floods or other hazards, such as minimum foundation height and building materials.

•	Additionally, qualitative information on buildings' flood history was collected where individuals were present (e.g., 'Has this building been flooded in the past?'

•	In the Manatuto area, a subset of residential buildings was mapped alongside all critical infrastructure buildings.


Field mapping activities covered the following areas and dates:

•	Manatuto: September 11th to 15th, 2023 (1479 critical infrastructure & residential buildings mapped)

•	Raimea: September 18th, 2023 (27 critical infrastructure buildings mapped)

•	Uma Berloic: September 19th, 2023 (36 critical infrastructure buildings mapped)

•	Pante Macassar: September 21st to 22nd, 2023 (218 critical infrastructure buildings mapped)


The data package includes the following files:

1_Timor-Leste_AA_mapping_all areas.xlsx: 
Contains all collected, georeferenced data in raw and cleaned formats, along with a codebook.
2_TL_AM_Data_joined_OSM_Buildingfootprint.zip & 3_TL_AM_Data_joined_OSM_Building_footprint.json: 
Contain collected data joined to the OSM building footprint, updated via satellite mapping before field activities.

4_TimorLeste_KoboForm_Questions.pdf: 
Displays the questions and answer options used in the KoboCollect questionnaire for field data collection on historic flood events, impacts, and early warnings.

5_Final_Datamodel_Koboform_TimorLeste_AAmapping.xls: 
This table contains the data structure of the KoboCollect questionnaire. Importing this file into the KoboCollect toolbox allows to replicate the data collection.
6_OSM_Data_Model.pdf: 
This table offers an overview of the OpenStreetMap (OSM) data model and tags used for anticipatory mapping in Timor Leste, detailing how geographic objects are tagged with keys (e.g., "building") and values (e.g., “residential”) to describe their attributes.

These two notes describe the input data, estimation and projection methods, and strengths and limitations of the resulting COD-PS update. These notes are made available to end-users of the 2024 COD-PS update.", "name": "cod-ps-ukr", "notes": "![UNFPA Logo](https://data.humdata.org/image/2021-08-05-143409.352392UNFPA-logo.jpg)

Subnational Population Statistics are produced by and contributed to HDX by [UNFPA](https://data.humdata.org/organization/unfpa) and, in the case of Ukraine, are exceptionally shared by OCHA Ukraine with the approval of UNFPA.

The 2024 Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) update for Ukraine presents raion-level (ADM-2), oblast-level (ADM-1) and national-level (ADM-0) estimates of population size by sex and standard 5-year demographic age groups. The 2024 COD-PS update revises the 2023 COD-PS update and 2022 COD-PS update produced by UNFPA, by accounting for recent population change due to mobility, mortality and fertility dynamics.

This COD-PS update was prepared by the United Nations Population Fund, UNFPA. This update was prepared in consultation with the Humanitarian Country Team and UN Country Team in Ukraine, as well as national partners including the Institute for Demography and Quality of Life Problems, Ukraine and the State Statistics Service of Ukraine.

The 2024 COD-PS update, like all COD-PS updates, is strictly a humanitarian data product of the United Nations aligned to the "best available humanitarian data standard". It does not represent or, in any way, replace official statistics or official population projections of the Government of Ukraine and it is not intended to meet the international standards of official statistics.

The Ukraine Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) 2024 is a restricted dataset, in line with applicable national laws and the host country agreement with the United Nations. message_content:
We need information on the number of IDPs in cities, communities, districts, and the region all over Ukraine.
We need this information to write projects that will be supported by Red Cross movement partners. The projects are aimed at supporting the resilience of IDPs. Having the number of registered IDPs divided by cities, communities, districts, and regions allows us to implement the project competently (implement it where it is most needed).

message_content:
Je voudrais avoir ces données dans le cadre de mes recherches pour mettre en pratique mes compétences en analyse de données acquises lors de différentes formations en ligne Python.

Je rêve décrocher un poste de  chargé de suivi et évaluation dans le secteur humanitaire. Je suis convaincu que des analyses statistiques poussées peuvent apporter une valeur ajoutée significative aux projets humanitaire. En effet, en allant au-delà des simples analyses descriptives, il est possible de :

Détecter des corrélations et des tendances cachées qui pourraient passer inaperçues lors d'une analyse superficielle; Identifier les facteurs de risque et les déterminants des inégalités sociales;Évaluer l'impact réel de nos interventions et optimiser les  stratégies.
Je souhaiterais contribuer à cet objectif en réalisant des analyses statistiques approfondies sur les données de votre organisation.

Tandis que l’accès humanitaire représente un obstacle de plus en plus tangible à la collecte d’information, en raison du caractère enclavé de certaines zones et du contexte sécuritaire volatile, les données disponibles sont généralement spécifiques à une intervention, un lieu ou un secteur.

Afin de répondre à ces défis en termes de gestion de l’information, REACH, sous le mandat du GCIS a facilité pour la première fois en Haïti une Evaluation multisectorielle des besoins (MSNA) qui couvre l'ensemble du territoire afin d'informer le Cycle de programmation humanitaire (HPC) 2023.

La collecte de données a eu lieu du 12 juin au 13 septembre 2022. 3896 ménages ont participé à l'enquête, dont 1188 dans la Zone métropolitaine de Port-au-Prince. Les entretiens ont été effectués en personne.

REACH Initiative a effectué la collecte pour les ménages en population générale. L'échantillon est stratifié par grappes avec un niveau de confiance de 95% et une marge d'erreur de 10%. Les données sont disponibles au niveau des départements et des milieux (soit rural, soit urbain), et au niveau des communes pour la Zone métropolitaine de Port-au-Prince. L'échantillon n'a pas pu être complété pour le département de l'Ouest en zone rurale du fait des contraintes sécuritaires de septembre 2022, les résultats sont donc à considérer comme indicatifs. Pour les populations déplacées et rapatriées, les données ont été collectées par l'OIM.

Le questionnaire a été mis au point avec les partenaires sectoriels et les groupes de travail thématiques. Il est traduit en créole haïtien.", "num_of_rows": 3896, "num_resources": 0, "num_tags": 13, "organization": {"id": "8e8911ab-f35c-4189-9dce-8715002f723e", "name": "reach-initiative", "title": "REACH Initiative", "type": "organization", "description": "REACH facilitates the development of information tools and products that enhance the capacity of aid actors to make evidence-based decisions in emergency, recovery and development contexts. Multi-Sectoral Needs Assessment (MSNA) is a tool used by the humanitarian community to determine the nature and scale of a crisis and the needs of a given population in specific geographic locations through the collection of primary data. message_content:
As a senior analyst focused on Afghanistan, I am conducting research on the humanitarian and economic situation in the country. The WoAA 2023 data would be invaluable for our analysis of needs and vulnerabilities across Afghanistan, which informs our policy recommendations aimed at preventing and mitigating conflict.
Crisis Group has been registered as an NGO in Afghanistan since 2002, and we are committed to using this data responsibly and in accordance with HDX terms. We would ensure the data is only accessed by authorized staff for research purposes. Any public outputs using the data would appropriately credit REACH and HDX.
Please let me know if you need any additional information about our intended use. We appreciate your consideration of this request.

message_content: There are new opportunities from UNHCR that have been announced in UNPP portal. AKAH would like to apply for these opportunities and will provide some information from the Whole of Afghanistan Assessment. We would be very much happy to use this assessment as a reference.
extras: {"country": "Afghanistan", "organization_id": "Aga Khan Agency for Habitat, Afghanistan (AKAH,A)", "organization_name": "Aga Khan Agency for Habitat, Afghanistan (AKAH,A)", "organization_member": false, "organization_type": "international_org", "intend": "Humanitarian Assistance", "dataset_dict": {"archived": false, "author": null, "author_email": null, "batch": "93c52ec2-af4f-4c42-b289-47be54a087d7", "caveats": "The Whole of Afghanistan Assessment (WoAA 2020) implemented a quantitative methodology reliant upon approximately 12,592 household level surveys in accessible parts of Afghanistan from 04 August 2020 to 05 September 2020. The Covid-19 pandemic increased commodity prices, decreased livelihood opportunities, and strained Afghanistan\u2019s weak health and social service infrastructures. Given the generally poor mobile and WiFi services across Afghanistan and the particularly poor access that vulnerable and displaced populations have to mobile phones and computers, face to face interviews were conducted. However, in recognition of the \u201cDue No Harm\u201d and \u201cDuty of Care\u201d principles, new procedures and trainings were established to limit both field staff and respondent exposure to Covid-19, survey questions were limited to only those crucial to cluster planning, the confidence rate for the sampling was increased, and focus group discussions (FGDs) were eliminated. \r\nData collection was conducted using stratified cluster sampling with a 95/5 at national level for all population groups. To reduce gender bias, male-female enumerator pairs conducted assessments in provinces where it was feasible to do so. Male-female enumerator pairs interviewed one male member and one female member of each household, when possible, using the same questionnaire. The number of kits for different age and gender groups within the programme should be proportionate to their demographic breakdown.

These two notes describe the input data, estimation and projection methods, and strengths and limitations of the resulting COD-PS update. These notes are made available to end-users of the 2024 COD-PS update.", "name": "cod-ps-ukr", "notes": "![UNFPA Logo](https://fn.no/assets/images/FN-kunnskap/Organisasjoner/FNs-befolkningsfond-UNFPA/unfpa-logo.png)

Subnational Population Statistics are produced by and contributed to HDX by [UNFPA](https://data.humdata.org/organization/unfpa) and, in the case of Ukraine, are exceptionally shared by OCHA Ukraine with the approval of UNFPA.

The 2024 Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) update for Ukraine presents raion-level (ADM-2), oblast-level (ADM-1) and national-level (ADM-0) estimates of population size by sex and standard 5-year demographic age groups. The 2024 COD-PS update revises the 2023 COD-PS update and 2022 COD-PS update produced by UNFPA, by accounting for recent population change due to mobility, mortality and fertility dynamics.

This COD-PS update was prepared by the United Nations Population Fund, UNFPA. This update was prepared in consultation with the Humanitarian Country Team and UN Country Team in Ukraine, as well as national partners including the Institute for Demography and Quality of Life Problems, Ukraine and the State Statistics Service of Ukraine.

The 2024 COD-PS update, like all COD-PS updates, is strictly a humanitarian data product of the United Nations aligned to the "best available humanitarian data standard". It does not represent or, in any way, replace official statistics or official population projections of the Government of Ukraine and it is not intended to meet the international standards of official statistics.

The Ukraine Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) 2024 is a restricted dataset, in line with applicable national laws and the host country agreement with the United Nations. It is shared only with the Ukraine Humanitarian Country Team, UN Country Team in Ukraine, and the Government of Ukraine.", "num_resources": 0, "num_tags": 1, "organization": {"id": "40cfa9c2-59b6-44c2-bd34-cf99ce438067", "name": "ocha-ukraine", "title": "OCHA Ukraine", "type": "organization", "description": "United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in Ukraine.", "image_url": "", "created": "2015-06-11T18:38:28.045449", "is_organization": true, "approval_status": "approved", "state": "active"}, "overdue_date": "2025-12-08T21:51:01", "owner_org": "40cfa9c2-59b6-44c2-bd34-cf99ce438067", "package_creator": "shcheglov", "pageviews_last_14_days": 86, "private": false, "qa_completed": false, "review_date": "2024-09-25T19:23:00.253351", "solr_additions": "{"countries": ["Ukraine"]}", "state": "active", "subnational": "1", "title": "Ukraine: Subnational Population Statistics", "total_res_downloads": 8, "type": "dataset", "updated_by_script": "HDXINTERNAL:HDXPythonLibrary/6.2.0-CODs (2024-10-09T21:51:01.022328)", "url": null, "version": null, "groups": [{"description": "", "display_name": "Ukraine", "id": "ukr", "image_display_url": "", "name": "ukr", "title": "Ukraine"}], "tags": [{"display_name": "baseline population", "id": "db8205e9-b61c-4df7-a987-1a2658ed8666", "name": "baseline population", "state": "active", "vocabulary_id": "b891512e-9516-4bf5-962a-7a289772a2a1"}], "resources": [], "relationships_as_subject": [], "relationships_as_object": [], "is_fresh": true, "update_status": "fresh", "x_resource_grouping": []}}

message_content:
Dear colleagues, I am writing to you to request data on migration within communities (hromadas). As we are currently in need of researching a part of Ukraine's territory within the framework of the youth theme "Resilience and potential of restoring the agrarian sphere of  territorial communities of  the  Kyiv  Prydniprovia region,  affected by  Russian aggression" (State registration number 0124U002053). 
We are planning to comprehensively assess the impact of the war on the agricultural sector of the study area, where the population is also a relevant part of the study. 
1) So far, we have processed the data on the estimated population as of 1 January 2024, analysed the areas of influence and some of the events that took place there as a result of the hostilities (links to our work https://openreviewhub.org/geoterrace/paper-2024/analysis-resilience-agrarian-sphere-territory-kyiv-prydniprovia-region-context). 
2) For some communities, we have mapped the bombing zones, and when we visited the communities to take soil samples, we noticed that a significant proportion of fields are currently under cultivation, while small plots used by people are not always.
Therefore, we have a hypothesis that the number of people living in these areas is much lower today than before the outbreak of hostilities and the number of people who have returned does not match the level before the war. In this way, we want to estimate the percentage of changes (losses) and opportunities for population recovery as an engine for the development of the agricultural sector in the communities of Kyiv, Zhytomyr, Chernihiv and Cherkasy regions.
We understand the sensitivity of this data, so if we receive data, all information will be calculated in relative terms (percentage of the total population as of 1 January 2022, or per 1000 inhabitants, or percentage of returnees within the communities). The primary data obtained will be used only for calculations and will not be distributed beyond our working group.

The appeal is also related to the impossibility of obtaining them from statistical departments and directly from communities on the ground.

Sincerely, O. Leiberiuk

message_content: My academic research aims to analyze the 2020 National Health and Demographic Survey data. By identifying and clustering distinct profiles within the results, I seek to provide valuable insights for policymakers. These findings will support the development of more effective national health policies.

The survey provides valid, reliable and representative national and sub-national data, on mortality, fertility, birth spacing, maternal and child health, nutrition and gender-based violence. This data is critical to the development of sound national and sub-national evidence-based policy, to effective planning and service delivery, and to the monitoring and evaluation of performance by service providers and development projects and programmes.

You can get the microdata at [https://microdata.nbs.gov.so/index.php/catalog/50/study-description](https://microdata.nbs.gov.so/index.php/catalog/50/study-description)

Please consult the official informs: [Somalia](https://somalia.unfpa.org/en/publications/somali-health-and-demographic-survey-2020) and [Somaliland](https://somalia.unfpa.org/en/publications/2020-somaliland-health-and-demographic-survey-slhds-launched)

Sample design

The sample for the SHDS was designed to provide estimates of key indicators for the country as a whole, for each of the eighteen pre-war geographical regions, which are the country’s first-level administrative divisions, as well as separately for urban, rural and nomadic areas. With the exception of Banadir region, which is considered fully urban, each region was stratified into urban, rural and nomadic areas, yielding a total of 55 sampling strata. All three strata of Lower Shabelle and Middle Juba regions, as well as the rural and nomadic strata of Bay region, were completely excluded from the survey due to security reasons. {"country": "Ukraine", "organization_id": "WFP", "organization_name": "WFP", "organization_member": false, "organization_type": "international_org", "intend": "Humanitarian Assistance", "dataset_dict": {"archived": false, "author": null, "author_email": null, "caveats": "The release of this dataset is conditional upon acknowledgement and adherence to the restricted terms of use. Please see [here](https://forms.gle/jfU48Rzpvhz4oYq89).", "creator_user_id": "579d0958-0446-4848-997b-ed267fe642b4", "data_update_frequency": "365", "dataset_date": "[2024-07-15T00:00:00 TO 2024-07-15T23:59:59]", "dataset_preview": "first_resource", "dataset_source": "United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA)", "due_date": "2025-08-28T16:39:42", "field_names": "Oblast,Raion,geographic area,p-code,age groups,sex", "file_types": "XLSX,csv,pdf", "has_geodata": false, "has_quickcharts": false, "has_showcases": false, "id": "434dcf6c-c3ae-4c0d-a50d-0e9144803851", "is_requestdata_type": true, "isopen": false, "last_modified": "2024-08-28T16:39:42.799007", "license_title": null, "maintainer": "9429fda5-d84f-42e4-890d-e03bf8297f7b", "metadata_created": "2024-07-07T07:35:15.729428", "metadata_modified": "2024-08-28T16:39:42.799007", "methodology": "Other", "methodology_other": "A technical accompanying note and an end-user release note have been prepared by UNFPA. These two notes describe the input data, estimation and projection methods, and strengths and limitations of the resulting COD-PS update. These notes are made available to end-users of the 2024 COD-PS update.", "name": "cod-ps-ukr", "notes": "![Alt text](https://fn.no/assets/images/FN-kunnskap/Organisasjoner/FNs-befolkningsfond-UNFPA/unfpa-logo.png) 



The 2024 Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) update for Ukraine presents raion-level (ADM-2), oblast-level (ADM-1) and national-level (ADM-0) estimates of population size by sex and standard 5-year demographic age groups. The 2024 COD-PS update revises the 2023 COD-PS update and 2022 COD-PS update produced by UNFPA, by accounting for recent population change due to mobility, mortality and fertility dynamics.
 
This COD-PS update was prepared by the United Nations Population Fund, UNFPA. This update was prepared in consultation with the Humanitarian Country Team and UN Country Team in Ukraine, as well as national partners including the Institute for Demography and Quality of Life Problems, Ukraine and the State Statistics Service of Ukraine.
 
The 2024 COD-PS update, like all COD-PS updates, is strictly a humanitarian data product of the United Nations aligned to the "best available humanitarian data standard". It does not represent or, in any way, replace official statistics or official population projections of the Government of Ukraine and it is not intended to meet the international standards of official statistics.   
 
The Ukraine Common Operational Dataset on Population Statistics (COD-PS) 2024 is a restricted dataset, in line with applicable national laws and the host country agreement with the United Nations. It is shared only with the Ukraine Humanitarian Country Team, UN Country Team in Ukraine, and the Government of Ukraine. Additional requests for access to this dataset and the accompanying documentation may be made to the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs and the United Nations Population Fund via this [link](https://forms.gle/jfU48Rzpvhz4oYq89). Such requests will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis.

As a food economist, my goal is to conduct research on the current food insecurity situation in Afghanistan and raise awareness about the issue. I will look into the 2023 data and try to identify and explain food insecurity across various regions of Afghanistan. The Afghanistan MSNA data is very relevant and helpful for understanding the latest food insecurity in Afghanistan. I aim to use MSNA and other data sources to identify potential policy solutions for helping Afghan people in their struggle with ongoing food insecurity.

message_content:
We are conducting a research project on refugee return intentions. As a part of the project, we hope to analyze UNHCR's refugee return intentions datasets to identify patterns across different contexts, examine trends over time, and characterize the methodologies used to measure return intentions. The study will describe data coverage, evaluate the specific questions used to gauge intentions, and analyze the latest developments in measurement techniques.

Methods include quantitative analysis of return datasets and a review of coding guides to record what survey questions were included.

The primary output will be a scholarly paper describing how return intentions are measured, with the aim to contribute to understanding of how to measure refugee return intentions in survey research.

This academic research project is conducted by researchers at UC Santa Barbara, Bocconi University, ETH Zurich, and Harvard University.
extras: {"country": "United States", "organization_id": "University of california santa barbara", "organization_name": "University of california santa barbara", "organization_member": false, "organization_type": "academic_research", "intend": "Academic"}

message_content: The primary output will be a scholarly article submitted to a peer-reviewed academic journal in the field of political science. The article will present aggregated findings on refugee return intentions, discussing trends and patterns across different contexts. No individual-level data will be published. We intend to make the research findings accessible to humanitarian and development practitioners through academic channels.

message_content:
New Access Consulting is currently conducting three longitudinal studies focusing on: Targeting, Exclusion, and Inclusion of Minorities and on Localization of Humanitarian Assistance across Somalia.
Our research emphasizes community perceptions of assistance, language challenges in accessing complaint feedback mechanisms (CFM), and other communication and advocacy mechanisms. We have gathered significant field data over the past year, including large household surveys and qualitative data collections.

To further our research, we kindly request access to your database. Specifically, we need data that includes:

- A breakdown of key complaints by region, district, and humanitarian actor
- Complaints categorized by clusters
- Verbatim quotes on key complaints, if available

We do not require access to identifiers or information that could reveal the identities of individuals who submitted complaints. Our objective is to analyze the general trends and themes within the data, which will inform our findings and recommendations without profiling complainants or organizations.

Thank you for considering our request. We believe that access to this data will significantly enhance our research and contribute to more effective humanitarian assistance strategies.
extras: {"country": "Somalia", "organization_id": "New Access Consulting", "organization_name": "New Access Consulting", "organization_member": false, "organization_type": "academic_research", "intend": "Academic"}

message_content: Norwegian Church Aid (NCA), with funding provided by the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is implementing a research project to support implementation of HDP nexus programming in NCA’s target location. Specifically, the data set will be used to better understand resilience, coping abilities, and social cohesion in the target locations. The WoAA data set would complement monitoring and evaluation data collected by the project. We are hoping to conduct advanced statistical correlation analysis to better understand interrelationships between coping abilities, resilience and social cohesion in the target locations. The research will draw on a variety of data sets, but the WoAA data set is one of the most important data sets, as it is the only statically representative study available that looks at related themes.

Hi,
We're running a research project investigating the dynamics of violence in Ukraine. Specifically, we conduct a quantative study on patterns of attacks against infrastructure. To do so, we're interested in data that helps us identify and exclude confounding indicators, such as displacement patterns. Would you be willing to share this data with us? By analyzing this data, we aim to identify potential correlations between certain pollutants and health outcomes, which can inform evidence-based interventions and policies to improve community well-being. Access to this data will enable us to contribute to the scientific knowledge in this field and ultimately help protect and enhance public health. We assure you that we will handle the data with the utmost care, ensuring data privacy and security in compliance with all relevant regulations. We are also open to collaboration and sharing our findings to foster collective understanding and contribute to the broader scientific community. We would be happy to address any concerns or questions you may have and are committed to using the data responsibly for the stated purpose."

message_content:
Dear Data Contributors,
I hope this message finds you in good health and high spirits. My name is Kiki Cai, a senior student at Barnard College, currently working on a research concerning the impact of COVID-19 on maternal mortality rates in Yemen.
I am writing to humbly request access to a dataset that encompasses the geographical distribution of health facilities within Yemen. My intention is to employ this resource in order to create a detailed mapping of these facilities, subsequently facilitating an in-depth analysis of maternal mortality rates by health district.
Your collective efforts in curating and maintaining this dataset are immensely commendable, and I am sincerely grateful for the invaluable contribution you are making towards advancing research efforts such as mine. Your generosity in sharing this data would be instrumental in realizing my research goals.
I extend my heartfelt thanks in advance for your consideration of this request.
extras: {"country": "United States", "organization_id": "Barnard College", "organization_name": "Barnard College", "organization_member": false, "organization_type": "academic_research", "intend": "Academic"}

message_content:
Dear IMU Manager,

I trust this email finds you well. My name is Khaled Najjar, and I currently serve as an information officer at the Watan Organization. Our organization operates under a Turkish license and is actively engaged in various initiatives spanning both Turkey and Syria.

I am writing to kindly request your assistance in obtaining a copy of the most recent population census results for Syria. Specifically, I am interested in the data that is displayed on the Dashboard. The purpose behind this request is to utilize the census information as secondary data to better assess our organization's needs and align our efforts accordingly.

Understanding the sensitivity and significance of such data, I want to assure you that our intent is to handle this information with the utmost professionalism and discretion

Could you please guide me on the process to access the aforementioned population census results? Any information on the necessary steps, documentation, or permissions required would be greatly appreciated. Furthermore, if there are any associated costs or fees, kindly provide those details as well.

I truly value your expertise and assistance in this matter. Your support will greatly contribute to our efforts to make informed decisions based on accurate and up-to-date data.

Thank you in advance for your time and attention to this request. I look forward to your response.

Best regards,

Khaled Najjar
Information Officer
Watan Organization

message_content:
Dear HDX team,

I am a Master's student in Development Economics at the University of Goettingen, Germany, originally from Afghanistan. I am writing to request your assistance regarding my upcoming thesis on Afghanistan.

I have reviewed the data available, specifically the Annual Whole of Afghanistan Assessment (WoAA 2022), conducted by your organization. While I was able to access the data from the 2018 assessment, I encountered difficulties in finding the data for the assessments conducted in 2020 and 2022.

As these more recent assessments are crucial for providing up-to-date information on Afghanistan, I kindly request your support in obtaining the data for the years 2018, 2020, and 2022. Access to this data would greatly contribute to the depth and accuracy of my thesis research.

I truly appreciate the valuable work your team carries out in conducting these assessments, and I recognize the importance of data sharing for academic purposes. I assure you that the data will be used solely for academic research, and I am committed to maintaining its confidentiality and complying with any relevant terms or conditions.

Thank you for considering my request. I would be immensely grateful for any assistance you can provide in fulfilling my data requirements. Please feel free to contact me if you require any further information or have any questions regarding my research.

Yours sincerely,
Ahmadullah Ahmadzai
Master's in Development Economics Student
University of Goettingen, Germany

message_content:
From our office in Latin America and the Caribbean, we are conducting a situational analysis of the Haitian and extra-continental Afro-descendant migratory flow to identify their humanitarian and protection needs, capacities, barriers, and risks they face, both in transit and destination in the Americas. Our focus of work during this year will be on three border points: the Colombo-Panamanian border, the Mexico-Guatemala border (Tapachula), and the Mexico-USA border.

We have been participating in the data collection efforts in Necoclí with GIFMM and other organizations. We know it contains valuable information on the profile of people, journey characteristics, and migratory routes. For this reason, I am contacting you to access the data.

Jairo Alberto Segura Dia (UNHCR) provided this link to access the data.

message_content:
Dear HDX team, 

I represent a team of students from the Kyiv School of Economics and Duke University. 
At the moment we participate in the mutual course on Tracking Warzone Economic Activity in Ukraine (ECON.390.04.Sp23).
As a choice for our group project, we decided to construct several econometric models based on nightlight index data, google trends queries, and population estimates in order to track changes in the IDPs levels.
In order to make the model as accurate as possible we would be really glad to test it on the early data of IDP estimates (March - September), prior to the stage when it became significantly affected by power outages and blackouts in the country. For this reason, we would be really happy to obtain the data in question.
Thank you for your help and support in advance,

If any further confirmation or proof of interest is needed, 
do not hesitate to contact me straight away.

Kind regards,
Petro
extras: {"country": "Ukraine", "organization_id": "Kyiv School of Economics ", "organization_name": "Kyiv School of Economics ", "organization_member": false, "organization_type": "academic_research", "intend": "Academic"}

message_content:
Hello, Dear OCHA team, 

I am a Ph.D. student at Oregon State University examining social policy topics in Afghanistan. I am writing to inquire about the possibility of accessing Humanitarian Access Incidents (HAI) 2019-2022 to examine how exposure of humanitarian organizations (attained from the 3W dataset) to access incidents (from the HAI), and violent conflict events (from ACLED dataset) along with other district level sociodemographic characteristics impact the operational presence and capacity of a humanitarian organization in the conflict-affected region during a global pandemic and political turmoil. 
The data will not be shared with anyone without a written agreement from the OCHA.

We have been working for UNEP on tracking environmental incidents in Ukraine and have now been commissioned by the OSCE to co-ordinate a preliminary assessment of the environmental damage and risks of the first 12 months since Russia’s invasion.

This includes consolidating available evidence and covering a very wide remit of environmental themes. An understanding of the movement and location of IDP is an important element, regarding environmental risks and impacts.

The IDP data will be used to understand where there may be increased pressure on natural resources, or risks to IDP. The raw data will not be shared, yet used to evaluate risks e.g. to water resources, ecologically sensitives area or environmental infrastructure.

The Healthy Communities Program of the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) seeks to support the strengthening of Colombia's health system in order to sustainably integrate the migrant population, the Colombian returnee population and the host communities, as well as to respond to health emergencies. Within this framework, the program is conducting an analysis of the implementation processes of projects financed with international cooperation resources with a health approach. The main objective of the study, carried out in coordination with the Ministry of Health and Social Protection, is to learn about the processes and impacts of projects developed focused on the provision of health care services  (sexual and reproductive health, maternal and perinatal health, HIV, mental health).

The Conflict and Environment Observatory (CEOBS, www.ceobs.org) is currently curating a database on the environmental damages caused by the invasion of Ukraine, supported with UNEP and others. 
One element of the database is calculating an 'environmental risk score'. One component of this score is exposure to hazardous pollution -estimated by assessing the population density in different radii around an incident. Where the population density is high, there is a bigger risk of environmental health problems, and hence we want to score such events incidents higher.
The Meta population density map would be ideal for this given we want radii from close (50m) to an incident epicenter.
At the moment, we are just interested in overall population density, but it would be interesting at some point down the line to see if there are gendered or other demographic patterns in the environmental risk.

Dear yours,

I am a post doctoral researcher at the Social Computing department at Qatar Computing Research Institute (QCRI - HBKU). I am currently working on a project with Dr. Ingmar Weber and Dr. Ferda Ofli, whereby we aim at estimating and predicting the internal displacement of Ukraine civilians in the current war context based on car counting. Part of our research is based on gathering high resolution population density maps, whereby the present data would be very relevant for our research purposes. More specifically, we would like to use the data to use as a potential predictor (i.e., covariate) in the spatio-temporal statistical model we are currently building.  In this sense, I would kindly ask for your permission to share the current data.

I would be more than happy to share more details on the project, if you deem necessary.

Thank you in advance for your time and consideration.

Kind Regards,
Marie-Christine Rufener

message_content:
Message for contributor: 
Why are you requesting access to this data? Please be as specific as possible about your role and your intended use of the data.

Hello, I am doing a damage and needs assessment for Ukraine. One of our sectors is health facilities and in looking for datasets online I came across this one. With your permission I would like to use it to help me accurately locate health facilities within Ukraine. I hope you take it into consideration.

V/r

Hello, I am requesting access to this data as I am doing a damage and needs assessment within Ukraine and understanding the population density is essential in doing it accurately. We have a quick turnaround and gaining access to this information is of high priority.
Dear Colleagues, we are trying to create an overall overview of the destroyed infrastructure in Ukraine. Unfortunately, we currently do not have access to such a source.
to conduct a city profile of Derna on behalf of UN Habitat

Hello, I am requesting access to this data to be able to create a map using ArcGIS software to visualize various demographic features, such as population, in relation to other factors such as food insecurity as part of a project for a college class.

Hi,  

My name is Devin Burke, a researcher in Ryan Layer's lab at the University of Colorado Boulder.  We are working with World Bank to construct a data pipeline that would allow for the analysis of refugees and better deployment of aid in the region.  We currently are looking at all of the countries immediately surrounding Ukraine, however we could use the negative flux of Ukraine to get a further understanding of the movement of refugees.  Thank you for you time.

Working with UNCN, a network of 30+ NGOs (primarily 501c3s). We are currently supporting the evacuation of refugees fleeing the war in Ukraine and provide on the ground direct assistance to communities in need. Would like access in order to provide situational awareness on damaged infrastructure.
i work for the eu, and we need to understand the movements of Ukrainians - thanks!
I work for the EU, we need to understand movements of Ukrainians.
Request for data

I am a remote sensing scientist and I deal with the classification of satellite data using machine learning algorithms. I would like to contribute to the damage analysis using new and quick to implement algorithms.
I lead the IRC's crisis analysis work and we are developing maps to support our programmatic planning in Ukraine
for updating reports
I work as a data analyst at the OPC and I need to know the current population numbers, even with acceptable accuracy
I am student learning IMO health information management officer at health cluster taking online training course now finished so I need this Data I am building my final course project

At CLEAR Global (formerly known as we do research and produce products and analyses to inform the humanitarian community about issues of language and communication in crisis situations.  We are currently working on a number of products and projects related to the Ukraine crisis and are looking at sources of data for population movements to build data models around. See here for more about our work: https://clearglobal.org/partner-with-us/ukraine-appeal/
good morning, It would be possible to take this dataset, in order to support Spanish Red Cross teams that is working in the borders between Hungary and Ukraine. Thank you.
Analyst for Insecurity Insight, documenting attacks on health facilities in Ukraine. Intend to use data to cross-reference images/ satellite data to identify damage to health facilities.

I am a student at the Fletcher school at Tufts University who is intending to use the health facility data to do an analysis of the vulnerability and humanitarian aid in each Ukrainian oblast. Healthcare facilities would be one data point incorporated into the vulnerability analysis.
I work for the EU managing flows of refugees and so we need to know as much as possible about IDPs and those crossing the border - thanks!
I have a GIS background and would like to use the dataset for my maps.

I am working in the data team of Bonn International Center for Conflict Studies (BICC) in Germany. We would like to access the data for creating insights into population dynamics resulting from the ongoing war in Ukraine.

Good morning, in orther to support the Spanish Red Cross health deployment close the Ukraine-Hungary border. We would need to know about health sites in the area. It would be possible to access this dataset? Thank you so much.

I am working on the response for the WHO Ukraine conflict and would like access to this data for internal use in understanding population movements following the crisis. This will help us understand where to direct health services

Hi there,
At MSF a detailed look at the data used in the report "Violence Against or Obstruction of Health
Care in Ukraine" would be very useful to us.  We would use this data for an internal only GeoApp which helps our team support Health Facilities in Ukraine and also help manager our team's security.
Thanks
Ken BRAGG
MSF GIS Data Manager

We are a UK NGO charity that works in countries across the world to identify and clear mines and unexploded ordnance. As part of our work we identify distribution of population in 'as was' situation, then review how the population moves in conflict in relation to identifying risk areas for priority clearance. We have WorldPop raster data, but wish to explore benefits provided by the Meta dataset
To assist situational awareness, mapping of the Ukraine conflict, to determine logistics on the ground, ahead of potential deployment of clearance staff - for mines and other un-exploded ordnance

Zipline is trying to assess whether or not it would be viable for us to support with distribution of medical supplies into, within, and around Ukraine. The locations of medical and healthcare facilities is vital for us to establish where we could base an operations with a ~100km radius catchment area.
Project for Utrecht University
Project For University
We are preparing and assessment of conflict events and would like to include proximity to health facilities. The assessment will be shared exclusively with USG agencies supporting Ukriaine.

We are preparing an estimate of damage and would like to assess the conflict event with respect to school locations. We intend to share this information exclusively with USG agencies supporting Ukraine.
Our company is working on a GIS product in support of the International Medical Corps and we feel this data would be invaluable to our current efforts. Thank you for your time.

I am working with UNOCHA on the Ukrainian response and would like to investigate this dataset for the possibility of mapping the data. I have already used the summary data available so would like to know what other variables this more detailed dataset contains.
Many thanks.

My name is Maddy Mulder and I am a fellow within the geolab, a data science research lab at the College of William & Mary in the United States. We recently announced the release of geoBoundaries, an open source geospatial data extraction tool provided to the research and analyst community. This tool has freely been used by thousands of policy analysts, program evaluators, and scientists to conduct analyses of development policies and programs using geospatial data.  It allows anyone to easily obtain datasets that fuse together georeferenced data on development investments with a battery of other measures from satellites, surveys, and weather stations.

A critical limitation of this tool is that we are currently using geographic administrative boundaries with many known errors.  As such, we are reaching out to our in-country partners, GIS practitioners, and others in the field to construct a fully open-source boundary dataset to both (a) integrate into the GeoQuery tool, and (b) release as a public good.  As we went through this process, we came across the shapefile you uploaded to the Humanitarian Data Exchange for Afghanistan's boundaries. This message is to seek your permission to obtain and redistribute these shapefiles under an open source license which will enable other researchers to download and use your boundary information with minimal restrictions. If you are open to our use and distribution of your boundary information, we would deeply appreciate a response to this email providing an affirmation.

Finally, if you have any additional information on individuals we might contact for more up-to-date information (if it exists), we would welcome such information.

Dear colleagues, hello 
I'm a former OCHA employee and currently supporting GIS activities for the FAO Hand-in-Hand Initiative. Knowing that the most updated data on admin boundaries are available on HDX, I would kindly ask you to provide shapefiles or grant access to the Global International Boundaries UN Map. The Hand-in-Hand is FAO's evidence-based, country-led and country-owned initiative to accelerate agricultural transformation and sustainable rural development to eradicate poverty (SDG 1) and end hunger and all forms of malnutrition (SDG2). In doing so, it contributes to attaining all of the Sustainable Development Goals. The initiative prioritizes countries where national capacities and international support are the most limited or where operational challenges, including natural- or man-made crises, are the greatest.
Currently, we're working on the extraction of the admin boundaries for the beneficiary countries. 
Please advise whether the provided information is sufficient enough to obtain the data or more expanded information on the FAO Hand-in-Hand Initiative is needed. 

Thank you in advance.

We are conduction a project in Afghanistan, in partnership with Integrity Watch Afghanistan and the Special Inspector General for Afghan Reconstruction (SIGAR), to create a geolocalized database of public infrastructures in the country. These include schools, hospitals, electric poles, waterpumps, sustaining walls, mosques, markets, bridges, irrigation canals, etc. The collected information includes photos, gps coordinates, construction dates, donors, management, funding, usage, capacity measures, general condition, etc. 

This is a very useful dataset by itself, but we intend to use the information to generate community monitoring programs of infrastrcutures with Integrity Watch to have citizens monitoring their public infrastructures. 

We lack however precise data on districts in the country. Our GPS system is not able to correcty identify the district the infrastructure is in because this is not widespread information. We believe that this administrative dataset would help us a great deal in having more precise information on the location, for future provincial and district level analysis.

I am with People for Peat (PFP), a coalition of 3 NGOs from Indonesia and Malaysia (WRI, IDH, and TRCRC) working on the non-state actor portion (Component 2) of the EU-funded "Sustainable use of peatland and haze mitigation in ASEAN" (SUPA; 2019-2022). We are in the midst of mapping communities in ASEAN member states that live around peat swamp areas and their associated economic activities in a bid for us to catalyze external investments that will help to make existing businesses on peatlands become more sustainable - in effect teaching peat communities to manage their lands better without burning to get a viable income so that the annual transboundary haze issue can be averted/reduced. An up-to-date land cover map for Indonesia would be very helpful for us in scoping for the most viable areas for project development. Thank you for your time and consideration.

Jo Kien
Lead Analyst
PFP

Regarding a request to access the data sets titled:

"DTM Round 1 Flow Monitoring of Venezuelan Migration - Peru"

I would like to clarify that this data will only be used for academic purpose on class project at The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy. I will not be disseminating the data in any way shape or form. My project consists of looking at how Venezuelan migration impacts departimental vulnerability taking into account the past two years. This project aims to asses where Venezuelan migrants are located, and what are the most vulnerable departments in Peru, with the hope of analyzing which regions would be most affected by the influx of Venezuelan migrants. 

This data set would be intergral  in understanding the financial and social integration of Venezuelan migrants in Peru. These data sets would be extremely helpful in moving ahead. 

I hope that this resolves any concerns as to what this data will be used for.

Right now, I am enroled in an Internship Program well designed to help to facilitate international youths’ professional learning on the one hand, and help Taiwanese enterprises to gain more internationalized experience and talents on the other. Hello,

My name is Jen, I work as a GIS technician for a research group at the University of Oxford (UK) called the Malaria Atlas Project. We work with collaborators such as the WHO, the Global Burden of Disease, and the Clinton Health Access Initiative to provide geospatial models of malaria incidence and prevalence at high spatial resolution (typically 5km grid cells). One of the inputs to these models are malaria case numbers provided against administrative unit names. However, these are typically not provided with the administrative boundaries required to make the data spatial, and matching the named units to geometries is one of the main problems we face. 

For Indonesia, the set of administrative boundaries we currently hold is out of date, with a number of units having been created in the past few years and therefore missing. It would be greatly appreciated if we could use your boundaries to see if they provide a better match. The boundaries would be used to feed data into our models for collaborators and academic papers, and the published outputs would not specifically display the units. They would not be explicitly shared without prior consent and due acknowledgement.

If you have any further queries about usage, please get in touch with me at jennifer.rozier@bdi.ox.ac.uk.

Kind regards,
Jen

Dear receiver,

We are a World Bank team estimating child undernutrition in the Philippines based on small area estimation. In this regard, we seek to have a shapefile with the lowest administrative level so that our results can be as accurate as possible.

The idea is that we take survey data from the NNS and estimate child undernutrition based on variables that are available in the most recent census and different spatial variables. Next, we extrapolate the survey results to the entire country.

We are looking forward to hearing from you.

Best regards,
Kasper Brandt

Dear HDX,

My name is Graham Melville and I am a fellow within the Research and Evaluation Unit at AidData, a research lab within the Institute for the Theory and Practice of International Relations. We recently announced the public beta release of GeoQuery, an open source geospatial data extraction tool provided to the research and analyst community. This tool has freely been used by thousands of policy analysts, program evaluators, and scientists to conduct analyses of development policies and programs using geospatial data.  It allows anyone to easily obtain datasets that fuse together georeferenced data on development investments with a battery of other measures from satellites, surveys, and weather stations.

A critical limitation of this tool is that we are currently using geographic administrative boundaries with many known errors.  As such, we are reaching out to our in-country partners, GIS practitioners, and others in the field to construct a fully open-source boundary dataset to both (a) integrate into the GeoQuery tool, and (b) release as a public good.  As we went through this process, we came across your Indonesia administrative boundary polygon data. This message is to seek your permission to redistribute these shapefiles under an open source license which will enable other researchers to download and use your boundary information with minimal restrictions.
